stream_context.summary: Kaze spent the whole session trying to create a convincing, low-poly "styrofoam" material for a mountain area. The work ranged from texture hunting and Blender experiments to planning an N64-friendly fake-bump-mapping technique.

development_findings.summary: Return to Yoshi’s Island will contain 15 courses in total.
development_findings.quote: There’s going to be 15 courses in total.

development_findings.summary: Kaze wants the mountain’s rock to look like styrofoam so the model can use fewer polygons and add visual variety.
development_findings.quote: This mountain here I think it would look better if it was made out of styrofoam and we could do this in less polygons.

development_findings.summary: He plans to fake bump-mapping with two 64×64 textures: a base texture and a highlight texture whose visibility is driven by vertex alpha based on camera/light angle.
development_findings.quote: We need one texture without the highlights and then a texture that is just the highlights that we multiply with shade alpha.

development_findings.summary: After hours of failures with displacement and AI textures, he settles on exporting a normal map, pre-rotating it into 5–8 orientations, and rewriting it every frame so the CPU simulates lighting; technique inspired by Daryl’s earlier single-direction hack.
development_findings.quote: We’re going to multiply the normals with the angle between the camera and the light and overwrite the normal maps every frame.

development_findings.summary: The method limits surfaces to a small set of allowed rotations (about 6–8) to keep data costs acceptable.
Lilaa’s earlier idea, already implemented across the game, saved roughly 30 instructions but introduced "very cursed" code.
development_findings.quote: Your idea worked… it saved like 30 instructions or so, unfortunately that means we have very cursed code like this.

development_findings.summary: Once affine matrices are added, a current divide-by-12 hack (6 instructions, ~10 ns) will be removed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is visibly frustrated by chat questions unrelated to the current task and says streaming social interaction drains him.
context_findings.quote: I really don’t want to talk about things. I want to just talk about making my game… I find it very exhausting to have to engage in social stuff when I just want to work.

key_stories.title: The Styrofoam Texture Odyssey
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent the entire stream chasing a convincing styrofoam look. Texture-site searches, AI generation, Blender displacement, and particle systems all failed. Eventually he devised a CPU-side normal-map trick and postponed implementation to next stream.
key_stories.challenge: Need a seamless, highlight-reactive styrofoam material that looks good and saves polygons.
key_stories.process: Tried JPEG textures, sponge photos, displacement in Blender, AI prompts, community-supplied photos, and particle systems; discussed limitations of N64 lighting; designed a multi-normal-map workaround.
key_stories.outcome: Decided to pre-compute and rotate normal maps and program a custom per-frame lighting routine; real work deferred.
key_stories.key_quote: I did not think making styrofoam would turn into this much of a disaster.

open_questions.context: Kaze outlined generating 5–8 rotated normal maps and rewriting them each frame to fake bump mapping.
questions: What exact performance cost does he expect on real N64 hardware?
How will memory be managed for the multiple rotated maps?
Could this technique be generalized for other materials?

open_questions.context: Current code divides by 12 in six instructions; Kaze said this will be replaced once affine matrices are in.
questions: What are the new affine matrices for?
How will they simplify or optimize rendering?

open_questions.context: He confirmed 15 courses exist but gave no detail.
questions: Have the individual course themes been locked in?
How far along is each course?
